!ENTRY org.eclipse.osgi Jul 16, 2004 09:17:02.770
!MESSAGE Bundle 
initial@reference:file:e:/eclipse/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime_3.0.
0/ [1] was not resolved.

Eclipse 3.0 requires a 1.4 Java VM and uses the JAXP APIs rather than a Xerces
plug-in for XML parsing.
*** Bug 73431 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Hi,

I have java1.4 on my system. Still its giving this error.
Is there any solution, which you can suggest me.

VG

The third line in the log file (from bug 73431) shows the Java version you are
running with is "1.3.1_01". You probably have this version in your system path,
so it ends up being found before the 1.4 VM. To make sure which VM is being
picked to run Eclipse, instead of tweaking your system path, it is recommended
that the -vm command line option be used when launching Eclipse. More info at:

http://help.eclipse.org/help30/topic/org.eclipse.platform.doc.user/tasks/running_eclipse.htm

BTW: you actually need at least a 1.4.1 VM (instead of 1.4.0).
*** Bug 76562 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 76946 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 80453 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 81862 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 86803 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

In my short three weeks with Eclipse, this is the second time I have restored 
my laptop from the scratch to get around the startup problem. First with 
SAXParser and last night with BundleException. I am too impressed with Eclipse 
to give up. After the first time I restored, I made sure there are no inferior 
releases of Java loaded for our baby to complain. So... it must be a lost or 
corrupt pointer. Can I reopen this?

The log file tells you what Java version you are using. If it is lower than 1.4,
see comment 4 on how to tell Eclipse exactly which VM to use. If it is 1.4 or
higher, then yours is a different problem , so please open a new PR describing
the problem and providing an error log.

I also am having this problem.  I am running java version 1.4.2, but the error
log says I am running 1.3.1.  I have checked the path variable, add/remove
programs area, and everywhere else I can think of to remove the old version, but
I cannot find it anywhere.  Can you tell me where else it might be hiding?

(In reply to comment #12)
I got it to work by simply putting the 1.4.2 in the beginning of the path
variable instead of at the end.
*** Bug 100706 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 101670 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 103053 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
